title: 115_hr4929
content: The Act is titled the "Stopping Improper Payments to Deceased People Act" and pertains to the distribution of death information by the Social Security Administration. The "Stopping Improper Payments to Deceased People Act" amends Section 205(r) of the Social Security Act to require the Commissioner of Social Security to transmit information on deceased individuals to ensure completeness, timeliness, and accuracy, with safeguards to protect the information. The "Stopping Improper Payments to Deceased People Act" requires federal and state agencies administering federally funded benefits to protect information on deceased individuals, including through cooperative arrangements with the agency's Inspector General, with reimbursement to the Commissioner of Social Security for associated costs. The Commissioner of Social Security must facilitate the use of deceased individuals' information for federal agencies, such as operating the Do Not Pay system, under certain conditions outlined in the "Stopping Improper Payments to Deceased People Act." The Commissioner may disclose personally identifiable information for various purposes, including ensuring proper payments under federal programs, tax administration, debt collection, and use by federal policing agencies for crime prevention and investigation. The Commissioner of Social Security can enter into cooperative arrangements with agencies and states to provide information on deceased individuals, with reimbursement for costs incurred. The reimbursement method must exclude any services or unrelated payments provided by the agency, and payments must be separately accounted for. The Commissioner of Social Security can use information on deceased individuals for specific purposes, subject to safeguards for protection. This includes use in state-funded programs, pension plans, and research activities. Additionally, certain amendments to the Social Security Act will be repealed after five years from the enactment of the Act. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to replace references to the Secretary of Health and Human Services with the Commissioner of Social Security. Additionally, a report to Congress on alternative sources of death data is required. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will review alternative sources of death data for Federal agencies, analyzing accuracy, interoperability, accessibility, cost, security, and reliability. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit a report to Congress on the review of alternative sources of death data for Federal agencies, including recommendations on extending access to Social Security death data. SEC. 8 of the Improper Payments Elimination and Recovery Improvement Act of 2012 amends the use of death data by government agencies. The Office of Management and Budget will issue guidance to agencies on improving data matching with death databases for beneficiaries and annuity recipients within 6 months of the enactment of SEC. 8 of the Improper Payments Elimination and Recovery Improvement Act of 2012. The Office of Management and Budget will develop a plan to assist states, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations in providing death records electronically to the Federal Government within a year of the enactment of SEC. 8 of the Improper Payments Elimination and Recovery Improvement Act of 2012. The Office of Management and Budget will develop a plan to improve data matching for payments to deceased individuals, involving consultation with relevant federal agencies, states, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations. The plan may include recommendations for funding to implement it. The Office of Management and Budget will work with tribal organizations to enhance data matching on deceased individuals receiving federally funded benefits. The Director will submit annual reports to Congress on the implementation progress, as defined by the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. SEC. 4. PLAN FOR ENSURING THE ACCURACY AND COMPLETENESS OF DEATH DATA MAINTAINED BY THE SOCIAL SECURITY ADMINISTRATION. The Commissioner of Social Security must submit a plan to Congress within a year to enhance the accuracy of death data, including data on individuals not receiving Social Security benefits. The plan should estimate the cost of implementing these improvements and consider procedures for identifying elderly individuals with no death record. The plan must enhance the accuracy of death data by verifying and correcting information in Social Security Administration records, including identifying alive individuals listed as dead and vice versa. Corrections made to the records should be disclosed when appropriate. The plan includes measures such as notifying the Social Security Administration of errors, improving policies to correct discrepancies in records, using statistical analysis to estimate erroneous records, and making legislative recommendations if needed. The Commissioner of Social Security must submit a report within 90 days of the Act's enactment to identify and describe security measures for information systems containing sensitive data.
